It's the best choice for family dinner if you don't care about the environment and the service. The dishes served very quickly though.
author: dove t.

description:
This place deserves NEGATIVE FIVE STARS for every rude remark the female waitress made while we were ordering and during the whole time we ate. My family and I UNFORTUNATELY ate at this restaurant. When we first arrived there were a couple of customers inside but it was mostly empty. The only person there to serve us was eating and didn't even bother to stand up up to greet us. When we ask questions about the dishes and check to see if they have clams or other seafood in stock the waitress would reply no in a rude manner as if we just insulted her. We wanted to order the $48 family dinner and it states clams as one of the dishes. My gf loves clams and my dad loves oysters, so we asked if we can substitute oysters and pay a little extra to replace clams since they don't have clams. The waitress tells us we can only substitute it with some lamb dish and they don't have oysters in stock either. We ask her if we can substitute the clam dish with some other seafood and she says it will cost at least $4 more to do that. Wow...her attitude, the policy of this restaurant, and the fact that she plain out doesn't care makes me want to leave. An extra for dollars to replace a similar seafood dish with another...rip off! She's lucky my parents were there or else we would've left. I don't think its too much of an expectation to get friendly customer service from a restaurant employee or just get the "i don't care" attitude from her without the rude and angry behavior.  We in no way said anything rude to her to get such harsh treatment from her. After the food was served we did let her know what we though of her rude, unacceptable behavior and that we would not be coming back nor recommend this place.

Besides the terrible customer service the food was ok. Portions are smaller than similar Chinese restaurants. The food did come out of the kitchen quickly which may be indicator they didn't take much time to cook quality food. The fried chicken dish had chips with it but the chips were stale and not crunchy. The chicken had way too much salt on it. The soup tasted and looked like it was just water and a little msg. The shrimp with walnut dish was just globs of mayonnaise with small shrimps hidden inside. The best part of the meal was the end when we left. Why? Because it was over! The waitress didn't even say thank you or bye. Maybe she was annoyed that we went in when she was eating or she had a issue earlier with a different customer, or she's on her period. Whatever the reason may be there is no reason to vent that anger and rude behavior on customers that want to enjoy a dinner together. I WOULD NOT RECOMMEND THIS PLACE TO ANYONE! STAY AWAY FROM THIS PLACE! THE FOOD HERE IS NOT WORTH IT, AND THE SERVICE WAS HORRENDOUS! I WILL NEVER COME BACK TO THIS PLACE AGAIN AND WILL MAKE SURE ALL MY FRIENDS DON'T COME HERE. I WOULD RATHER BUY THEM DINNER SOMEWHERE ELSE. If you are craving Chinese food in the Richmond neighborhood go to D&A on Clement. The food tastes better, the service is better, and they have fresh juice drinks.
author: Mike W.

description: This place deserves a solid 3 stars, but really varies.  I eat here a lot (or at least get take-out) since it's close to my abode.  The food is usually pretty consistent.  Service is spotty, but really, what do you expect from a Chinese restaurant?  Not the cleanest place to eat, but the prices are reasonable and the food is good.
author: Kris L.

description: It's not my favorite Chinese food (I find it bland), but it's a great value for money. Mains start around $4.50, and they usually throw in free rice and soup. The portions are so big that I've given up on trying to finish anything I order here. I eat half and take the rest home, which gives me two very cheap meals. It's cheaper and faster than cooking!
author: Aaron L.

description:
I visited at the suggestion of a friend (Chalmers!) and was not disappointed.  As other Yelpers advised, the fried chicken is indeed succulent, yet crispy!  Pineapple fried rice is also good, and the steamed crab did not disappoint, especially at around $20 for a whole crustacean.  The only average (not bad, just average) dish was their crispy noodles.

I went on a Tuesday afternoon and had no trouble getting a seat.  It was cool noting the crowd was a mix of contractors and locals who have probably been eating here several times a week for the past umpteen years.

I will return here when I come back to SF.  I will still get the crab even though I'll hit up PPQ Dungeness Island as the main objective in my next SF outing.

Warning: this is a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant with all the requisite diggings, including carpet that should have been changed out ca. 20 years ago.  But who cares?  You eat food off the plate, not the floor.
author: X. W.

description:
3 1/2 stars is what I would give to my experience at Emperor Palace, but since there's no half star, I'd think 3 stars would be more suitable than 4 stars.  

You get a pretty good deal at Emperor Palace.  The portions are HUGE for the price you pay.  Their seafood is fresh, but the way they cooked our fresh crab (we ordered salt & pepper crab) wasn't cooked right.  They used this tempura-like batter, which wasn't really what I wanted.  The fried quail was a bit too salty.  Besides these two dishes, everything else we had ordered was decent.
author: Katniss B.

description: $4.95 for a huge, steaming plate of seafood noodles? sign me up!
author: Brett W.

description: I love this place. The portions are large and the food is great. The ginger onion lobster is one of the best. When in season it's only 19.99 for 2 lobster. I would do dinner on the weekends only because I think they have a better cook for the busier weekends. When I have food there on the weeknights, it's a hit or miss with the food...can be a little bland at times.
author: Steven J.

description:
We come for dinner here only.  

Get the price fixe menu the one for $36.  It has crab, scallops, vegetables, oysters, clams.  

The food is delicious and plentiful.  Can't go wrong.
author: kenny l.

description: What my cousins drives up from San Jose just to eat here?  My brother, Grant and his wife, Liz (and her mama) came over and whisked me away to this tiny restaurant in the Inner Richmond District.  And,  we found in all the places to eat, my cousins from SJ on their way out the door after finishing their meal!  There was a small plate of toasted peanuts and the house soup(free) was served.  It's true their salt & pepper pork chops and chicken wings ($5.25) are tops.  We also order their Hong Kong style fried beef chow mein with bok choy ($3.95), Chinese Broccoli with Beef ($5.50), half Crispy Chicken  ($5.75). And of course, white rice (free) as well as their pot of tea (free).  Grant said if he had known how much I enjoy the Pork Meatloaf with salty fish  ($5.25) he would've ordered it.  I've learned later that this is a dish to bulk up on with your rice.  The entrees were huge and we had to have six boxes to take away.  After our dinner, the waiter bought us a sweet soupy bean dessert (free).   Ask for the Family meal style menu it ranges from $21.50 to $268.00.  Reservations for a large party. Just remember, when you order food to go, it doesn't taste as good and fresh.  I am coming back with my Wednesday Group for lunch next week!
author: Marian G.

description: I've been coming to this restaurant - however many times it's changed hands, since 1995.   It's my family's neighborhood go to restaurant because it's convenient - walking distance/no need to look for parking, cheap, fast  - all the reasons why one would dine at a hole in the wall Chinese restaurant.  Yes, it's true you get freebies like roasted peanuts, soup of the day - you never know what to expect, and dessert usually a bean type of sweet soup.  I've tried everything here from your typical chow fun, chow mein, salted fish fried rice to their ala carte, and fixed menu items.  Our family usually goes for the $35 fixed menu (I think 5 courses) dinner and adds or substitutes dishes.  I can't say the food is always consistent, some days are better than others.  However the service is consistent - the food always comes out fast and the people are well....typical.  I will continue to come here because of convenience sake, and it does suit my Chinese food craving most of the time.
author: Meredith K.

description: Really gross.  I ordered Szechuan Chincken.  The chicken was very, very low quality and super greasy.  I gave it one extra star because the guys serving us was really nice and hard working.  He was practically the only waiter in the whole room, serving a lot of people.
author: chad H.

description: I do not know how in the world this restaurant is rated 4 out of 5 stars. My boyfriend and I decided to try it after reading such great reviews on Yelp, but we were shocked by our experience. After seeing only one table full of people and the decor of the restaurant, we decided to order on the safe side. We ordered potstickers, kung pao chicken, and chicken fried rice, thinking these dishes were pretty generic. We thought wrong. I don't want to be very rude and say the things we really felt about the food... but let me just say this was the worst food I have ever had at a restaurant. We were pretty sure the "chicken" was just fat from a chicken covered in sauce, and the mystery meat in the potstickers was enough to make me sick to my stomach. I had never had a bad experience at a restaurant  in my life until last night, but it was so bad, we put cash down on the table and left as quickly as we could. All I can say is, do not eat here... and I do not know how the other reviewers' enjoyed Emperor Palace Restaurant's food as much as they wrote here on Yelp.
author: Megan L.

description:
OMG...I died and went to hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant heaven!  I have not had an experience like this in a long while..and I'm not talking about the food, although the food was pretty decent.  First off, I was born and raised in Chinatown...home of the hole-in-the-wall, grease on the floor, rude wait staff, cheap, plentiful and decent food.  I had my fill of these type of restaurants growing up, and being the child of a cook that worked at the old Joe Jung's, I know the meaning of the words "wok hei."  (For those of you that don't understand Cantonese, the best translation I can give is "fire flavor.")  After moving out of Chinatown, finding these types of restaurants were hard to come by....until now.....

I went to this place on a lark...I was around the neighborhood for a meeting and was scouting the area for some place to eat.  This restaurant was packed at 11 am, with lots of old Chinese (Cantonese/Toishanese speaking) people.  A good sign since we "lo wah kuei" people are known for frequenting places whose food are not just good but friggin' cheap.  When I walked in, the heads swiveled to see what new blood walked through the door as I did not look like anybody in the restaurant.  Thank goodness for my parents insisting I speak Cantonese to them or else I wouldn't have been able to get a seat.  No one brought a menu, and it wasn't until I was moved to a smaller table (did I mention it was packed?) about 10 minutes later that I reached over to the counter and grabbed a menu that I finally "got" a menu.  About another five minutes later the hostess/waitress came by and asked (in broken English) what I wanted.  Replied to her in Cantonese, and she ran off to the kitchen to place the order.  In between waiting for the food that I ordered, I noticed that patrons were going into the kitchen with a plate and coming out with peanuts...a bribe from the cook to get these guys out of the kitchen?  Got my food (tofu beef) about five minutes later - HUGE portions and was told rice was coming - about two minutes later.  The flavor of the beef was great - tender, and the tofu was silky.  In the midst of eating, a shipment of food supplies came in and almost didn't make it through the very tight rows.  I was able to see fresh vegetables and some still kicking fish.

All in all the experience was something that I haven't had in over five years.  I knocked it down one star as it took over 10 minutes to pay the bill.  Waitress didn't give an actual ticket on the total price of the food and was only told of the price verbally upon her throwing a couple of boxes for me to put my leftovers in.  All-in-all if you want the "real" Chinese hole-in-the-wall restaurant experience outside of Chinatown, this is definitely the place to go!
author: J H.

description: This place was pretty bad. The egg rolls were ok but the wor won ton soup and tomato beef pan friend noodle were gross. It seems like most of the dishes would be bad because im pretty sure they actually used ketchup in the tomato beef. Everything was slimy and the meat was bad.
author: rachel r.

description: this family style restaurant was surprisingly great!  food was fresh, flavorful and very good.  price is very very reasonable.  menu options are better than normal chinese restaurant choices.  great place around the neighborhood.
author: Silver C.
